s.text: Another posting stated "there is a tremendous amount of pro bono work done at BIGLAW (large law firms) in civil rights matters.
At least that is true in the big NYC firm where I practice."

A litigation associate suggested to others that "one thing I have seen regarding experience is that the younger associates who are motivated to do pro bono work, and actually get trial/court experience that way, do get rewarded with more significant work assignments for their efforts earlier in their careers.
As a frequent visitor to each site, I believe that they reflect the complexity of being a lawyer and the challenges of juggling financial success and public service.
The ultimate success of generousassociates or any other cause supported by the legal profession depends, in part, upon the financial success of the lawyers and law firms who support those causes.
As a frequent visitor to each site, I believe that they reflect the complexity of being a lawyer and the challenges of juggling financial success and public service.
The ultimate success of generousassociates or any other cause supported by the legal profession depends, in part, upon the financial success of the lawyers and law firms who support those causes.

The ultimate success of generousassociates or any other cause supported by the legal profession depends, in part, upon the financial success of the lawyers and law firms who support those causes.
A smart firm will have these people working on pro bono matters, writing articles ... "
A smart firm will have these people working on pro bono matters, writing articles ... "
What, if anything, do these seemingly polar opposite sites have in common or even say about our profession?
There's no reason to have nothing to do when there's an endless amount of pro bono work out there and maybe you will get a chance to learn something that you wouldn't get a chance to otherwise."

This person went on to ask, "Has anyone seen the AMLAW 200 pro bono ranking recently?
Although at first glance it might appear that they represent a clear choice between selfishness and generosity, these two sites and the underlying issues they address, are inextricably linked.
